body:
Hi @pavelbugneac, thanks for the kind words!
When stitching tracklets programmatically, we wanted the procedure to be universal and work independently of a configuration file (hence the dummy animal names). This flexibility allows one, for example, to easily reconstruct a varying number of tracks. As you rightly observe though, you could use it as follows:
```
import deeplabcut

cfg = deeplabcut.utils.read_config('config_path')
deeplabcut.stitch_tracklets(..., animal_names=cfg['individuals'])
```
The above is the default when done via the GUI 😊
I hope that helps!

body: Thanks for the support @jeylau ! Indeed it helps.

issue.body:
**Windows 10, DeepLabCut Version 2.2rc1, with an Anaconda Environment** **Describe the problem** Hello! I'm attempting to create a video after refining tracklets and following the steps so far, but i'm running into a key error when i'm attempting to render a video. In the input, i used the same config.yaml file, and my input is in the video folder - not my pickle file or any of the labeled videos, as those couldn't be read through the GUI. The specified tracker method is ellipses, and i didn't get this error when creating the labels, training the dataset, or refining the tracklets. Please place code inside this:
Code output

See error **Screenshots** ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/74156405/118174337-89749880-b3e3-11eb-8bf5-04b5d51a81f0.png) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/74156405/118174394-98f3e180-b3e3-11eb-9f44-dcd779c8835b.png) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/74156405/118174421-a0b38600-b3e3-11eb-8a6f-1bf62318f258.png) **Additional context** I've included screenshots of my config file in Atom in case there is an issue with the skeleton. Since the error is for individual 1, i assumed there was something wrong with the formatting there, but i can't find anything. Thanks for all of this incredible stuff, Mathis team!

body: Hey @pavelbugneac, just a quick update: the high level function `deeplabcut.stitch_tracklets` will now receive `config_path` as its first argument, so the desired (and arguably most common) behavior will be the default programmatically too 😊

many thanks for the ```animal_names=cfg['individuals']``` suggestion, super helpful @jeylau ! It works very well in projects where I do not have unique  body parts, yet in projects where I do, I have trouble implementing this suggestion.... Any idea how to adapt this for projects having varying numbers of identical animals in addition to unique body parts (single individual)?

Hey @felixhol, you shouldn't have to worry about that scenario, as the 'unique' individual gets labeled 'single' anyway, consistently with our other functions. The suggestion above should work, otherwise please let me know as that'd be a 🐛. What is important is the number of animal tracks to reconstruct (omitting the single individual, which is not really 'stitched' per se as it is only one unambiguous data sequence), and the number of 'multi' animal names given.
